channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Carney Holds Back on Tariff Retaliation, Says US-Canada Talks Are Progressing
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada won’t respond immediately to the Trump administration’s doubling of steel and aluminum tariffs, and indicated that officials are in “intensive discussions” about the trade relationship between the countries.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister.

item.title: Republican Tax Bill Adds $2.4 Trillion to US Deficits, CBO Says
item.description: The House-passed version of President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill would add $2.42 trillion to US budget deficits over the next decade, according to a new estimate from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol building in Washington, DC. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Weak US Services Activity, ADP Hiring Signal Some Tariff Strain
item.description: Activity at US service providers unexpectedly contracted last month for the first time in nearly a year and companies throttled back hiring, indicating the grip on the economy from higher tariffs is getting tighter.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: A workers plant flowers outside of Brooklyn Borough Hall in New York.

item.title: CBO Projects Trump Tariffs to Cut Budget Gap by $2.8 Trillion
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariff policies in effect as of mid-May would help to shrink US fiscal deficits by an estimated $2.8 trillion, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: Poland’s Fiscal Woes in Focus After Tusk Ally Loses Election
item.description: The defeat of Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s favored presidential candidate is shifting investor focus to the nation’s troubling public finances, amid growing concerns about political stability.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Russia’s Rainy-Day Fund Lost Around $6 Billion in May
item.description: Liquid assets in Russia’s National Wealth Fund, the country’s rainy-day reserves, declined by 14% in May, as increasing spending on the war in Ukraine and falling oil prices squeeze the budget.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin Photographer: Alexander Nemenov/Getty Images

item.title: Bank of Canada Holds at 2.75%, Says ‘Could Be a Need’ for Future Cut
item.description: The Bank of Canada held interest rates steady for a second consecutive meeting, but officials said there may be a need to cut borrowing costs if the economy weakens and inflation remains contained as US tariffs make an impact.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Canada in Ottawa, Ontario. Photographer: Kamara Morozuk/Bloomberg

item.title: Businesses Hiked Prices Quickly After Tariffs, NY Fed Study Says
item.description: Businesses have hiked prices quickly in response to tariffs, though only modestly cut headcount, according to a new study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that surveyed companies across the district.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Shoppers inside a store in the Chinatown neighborhood of San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday, March 27, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal consumption figures on March 28.

item.title: Poland Keeps Rates Steady at First Meeting After Election
item.description: The National Bank of Poland kept interest rates on hold, as expected, and gave no indication whether last weekend’s pivotal presidential election will impact the outlook for further reductions in borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, Poland's incoming president.

item.title: Morocco Launches Game Hub to Lure Developers, Boost Industry
item.description: Morocco is looking to secure a slice of the lucrative global gaming market, starting with the opening of a major industrial park, part of a plan to diversify the economy and boost export revenues.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam

media:content.media:description: Morocco's Gaming Expo in Rabat in May 2024. Photographer: Fadel Senna/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US Services Activity Contracts for First Time in Nearly a Year
item.description: Activity at US service providers slipped into contraction territory last month for the first time in nearly a year on an abrupt pullback in demand, while prices accelerated as higher tariffs reverberated across the economy.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Workers move boxes of appliance parts in a warehouse in Latham, New York.

item.title: EU, US See Progress in Talks Despite Trump Steel Tariff Hike
item.description: The European Union and the US are headed in the “right direction” in trade talks, though new American levies on steel and aluminum imports aren’t helpful if both sides want to maintain momentum, Maros Sefcovic said after meeting with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Maros Sefcovic, vice president of the European Commission, delivers a keynote speech on Brexit at Bloomberg LP's headquarters in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 29, 2022. The UK's plan to override the part of the Brexit deal governing trade in Northern Ireland won't work, Sefcovic said, stressing that the bloc wants an “enduring” partnership with Britain, and won’t contemplate establishing a hard border on the island of Ireland. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: US Hiring Cools to Slowest Pace in Two Years, ADP Data Show
item.description: Hiring decelerated to the slowest pace in two years as sectors including business services, education and health shed jobs, pointing to a weakened demand for workers.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

item.title: Bulgaria Set to Join Euro Zone in 2026 as EU Gives Support
item.description: The euro zone is set to continue its eastward expansion after Bulgaria was deemed ready to become the currency bloc’s 21st member.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: Customers at outdoor cafe tables in Sofia, Bulgaria. Photographer: Michaela Vatcheva/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Wants US Deal Done in Two Weeks to Save British Steel
item.description: Britain is hoping to complete a trade deal with the US in the next two weeks to avoid President Donald Trump’s vast new tariffs on steel, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Julian Harris

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares to wrap cold drawn stainless steel bars at a factory in Sheffield. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

item.title: World-Beating Cedi Slows Ghana Inflation to Three-Year Low
item.description: Ghana’s inflation rate dropped to the lowest level in more than three years, as the country’s world-beating currency helped reduce the cost of imports.
item.dc:creator: Moses Mozart Dzawu, Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: A vendor counts cedi banknotes at the Makola market in Accra.

item.title: South African Lawmakers Back Framework Underpinning Budget
item.description: A panel of South African lawmakers backed the National Treasury’s fiscal framework, the latest signal that the annual budget will finally win approval after twice being rejected by some members of the nation’s governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana

item.title: Milei’s Cuts Are Making Credit Harder to Collect in Argentina
item.description: President Javier Milei’s austerity drive has helped steady Argentina’s economy, and yet, financial pressure keeps mounting on consumers and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: Just over a year and a half since Javier Milei took office, Argentine businesses and households are under strain from stagnant wages and lingering inflation. Photographer: Sarah Pabst/Bloomberg

item.title: China Calls for France to Help Resolve Trade Differences With EU
item.description: China called on France to help resolve trade differences with the European Union, as Beijing seeks to shore up ties with the bloc amid simmering tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: Foster Wong

media:content.media:description: Wang Wentao

item.title: South African Finance Chief Awaiting Inflation-Targeting Report
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana said he is waiting for a report on the country’s inflation-targeting dispensation and he hasn’t decided whether it should be adjusted.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto, Mpho Hlakudi

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Outspoken South Korea Leftist May Alter Balance in East Asia
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics editor at Bloomberg in Sydney. Today we’re looking at South Korea’s new president. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

item.title: EU Calls Out One Third of Members for Breaking Its Fiscal Rules
item.description: A third of European Union countries with roughly half of the bloc’s population between them are now in violation of its fiscal rules, with Austria newly joining the pack.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Marton Eder

item.title: Trump’s Higher Steel Tariffs Sour Mood at Deal-Making Table
item.description: President Donald Trump’s doubling of US tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to 50% is fanning trade tensions at a time when Washington is negotiating with several economies that also face his so-called “reciprocal” duties set to kick in July 9.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: Norway’s House Prices Flat in May as Property Market Cools
item.description: Norway’s adjusted home prices stayed put last month, adding evidence that the market is taking a break from a recent rally as monetary easing is postponed.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

item.title: Israel Defense Exports Hit Record in 2024 as Europe Demand Jumps
item.description: Israel’s defense exports hit a record for a fourth consecutive year thanks largely to growing demand from Europe, even as some of its nations call for sanctions over the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: A Hermes 900 medium-altitude, long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicle at the Elbit Systems Ltd. stand at the International Defence and Security Technologies Fair in Brno, Czech Republic, on May 28. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Trump Tax Bill as Budget-Busting ‘Abomination’
item.description: Donald Trump ally Elon Musk lambasted the president’s signature tax bill as a budget-busting “abomination” as Republican fiscal hawks stepped up criticism of the massive fiscal package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul

item.title: Euro-Zone Private Sector Defies Tariffs to Grow Slightly in May
item.description: The euro area’s private sector grew slightly in May, remaining more resilient than initially estimated to the uncertainty created by erratic US trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Tractor manufacturing in Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Lagarde’s ECB Future Set for Scrutiny After WEF Job Speculation
item.description: Christine Lagarde is about to face scrutiny on her commitment to keep leading the European Central Bank, not least as she nears the milestone of having just about tamed inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Putin’s War Economy Roars Ahead and the Rest of Russia Struggles
item.description: The rift in Russia’s two-track economy is becoming wider as businesses tied to President Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine thrive and the rest are struggling for resources.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Rehearsals for Russia's Victory Day parade in Moscow in May.
